utterances: I think all of those places, certainly in terms of assassinations, there aren't that many, thankfully, that are the scenes of assassinations.
And because there are so few that fall into this category, all the more reason to preserve what we had.
Rick, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
Let's now talk to Linda.
Linda is with us from Flint in Michigan.
Yes, hi.
Hi.
Gosh.
I couldn't disagree more with the previous caller.
We need to honor these people.
We need to remember what happened so that history does not repeat itself.
I'm the president of the Castle Missions(ph) Historical Society.
It was an air battle that was the worst group loss in air history and we, with the Germans, have created a memorial on the spot where these planes went down and crashed.
And the Germans, when we had our dedication and rededication, they turn out - hundreds and hundreds of them turn out with bands.
And it's very, very important.
They sing the song ""Freedom,"" and we've been doing this forever.
What about the spot where Jesus was crucified?
These places are holy places and we need to honor these places that mean so much to a civilization.
Thanks very much, Linda.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
We're again, talking with Pat Morrison of the Los Angeles Times about - well, the strange fate of the pantry of the Ambassador Hotel where 40 years ago today Robert F.
Kennedy was assassinated.
If you'd like to join the conversation, our number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And this is Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Let's get Steve on the line, Steve with us from Wichita in Kansas.
Howdy.
Hi.
I've got a picture of myself and my wife standing next to chunks of the Berlin Wall.
This is in a museum in Hutchinson, Kansas, and somehow it doesn't seem like the Berlin Wall.
It's just a chunk of concrete with writing on it.
This isn't the kind of significance it would have had I actually seen the wall itself.
It is quite different.
We do our broadcasts on Wednesday from the Newseum.
There's also a chunk of the Berlin Wall there and again, it doesn't look anything like it looked when I remember walking through the Berlin Wall in - what, I guess about 1983 or so.

And it's different when the dogs are barking and the snow is flying and there's a guard in the tower with a machine gun looking down at you and you're wondering why you're walking in that particular direction.
Neal, I feel bit like Zelig(ph) because in 1989, in November, I was in London, and as soon as I heard about the wall I went over there and got to Berlin about midnight and walked along this wall.
And people had ladders and were climbing up to the top to look over and to talk to people in East Berlin.

And then apropos of the Kennedy thing, about 20 years ago, I was accompanying an older reporter to interview Sirhan Sirhan, shook the hand that pulled the trigger that killed Bobby Kennedy and then just a few months ago, visited the historical evidence vault in Los Angeles and put out my hand, that same hand and touched the jacket that Bobby Kennedy had worn that night.
There are so few opportunities for that immense power of the moment to play itself out for us in this country.
That's why I think it's important to save them.
Thanks very much for the call, Steve.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can get another caller in.
This is Robert, Robert with us from Wisconsin.
Good morning.
Or actually, good afternoon, I should say.
Good afternoon.
I have a comment and a question for Pat at the end.
My comment is, in our past, in this country, we have had, fortunately, very little bloodshed on incidents that led to great change.
Unlike other countries where assassinations may be part of the course, we have had very few in this country.
Now for that reason I believe we should save this because this assassination is forever going to be in the history books, because we've had so few.
That my comment being said, I have a question for Pat.
I know that these are only parts of the pantry.
But is it possible that the pantry could be recreated using these parts so people could get the dimensions and see what it was actually like at that point?
I suppose if there were historical institution that took over these parts they could recreate that, but it wouldn't be on the same site.
It would be wherever the historical institution is.
Say, the Smithsonian.
It might wind up in Washington, D.C., which would certainly help to give a sense of the place.
But it would never be the same ground, the same atmosphere.
And that's what I am sorry that we have lost in this opportunity.
You can recreate it and say, this is a piece of the actual wall.
This is the ice machine.
But as we heard earlier, it's like moving Gettysburg to Montana and saying, well, this is what it looked like, but it's not the actual place.
Almost the theme-parking of it.
I would hate for it to turn into that, like you said, the theme-parkiness of it.
But it would be better, I believe, than just getting the pieces and just laying them out like the other person said, like the Berlin Wall.
Better than nothing.
Thanks for the call, Robert.
It's interesting.
Again, at the Newseum, we happen to be backstage a lot because we do the broadcast from there.

But they are about to do an exhibition on the FBI and one of the things they have is the cabin of the Unabomber, which the FBI took apart piece-by-piece, and like one of the temples in Egypt that were going to be drowned by the lake formed by the Aswan High Dam, reassembled in another location.
And I guess for forensic purposes, they moved it all back to the lab.
And to see it all in pieces where it's going to be reassembled in a museum - and I guess to some degree, that's what the pantry of the Ambassador Hotel looks like right now.

It may eventually come to that, yes, because it started as a crime scene, then it became evidence, and finally it got bulldozed into history, save for these few pieces, which have been preserved and at some point, perhaps, will be used to help invoke exactly what happened.
Because this was a kind of battlefield itself.
Someone shed blood because he believed in something in this country.
Pat Morrison, thanks very much for your time today.
Appreciate it.
Always a pleasure, Neal, thank you.
Pat Morrison joined us from the studios of our member station in Pasadena, California, KPCC.
Ira Flatow will be here tomorrow with Science Friday.
We'll see you again on Monday.
This is Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Yeah.
I just talk about something now.
You know, like something that passed when you may just wrap it up and may the Lord be with you.
Peace.
(Soundbite of music)
Some people might actually welcome consolidation.
Alexa Conway is a 70-year-old retiree on a fixed income who lives in the Pacific Northwest.
She has Netflix, Amazon Prime and Hulu.
She canceled her cable subscription to save money and put up an antenna to get local TV stations.
She's a fan of the Denver Broncos.
On cable CBS, she got all their games.
She says now she would have to subscribe to CBS's streaming service All Access to watch them all.
She spoke over Skype.
And it really, really offended me.
I just thought, you know, there is enough to do if I want to sit in front of the TV and binge that I don't need to pay yet another service.
The kind of anger Conway is feeling may be having an unexpected impact.
For the first time in many years, there's growth in online piracy of film and TV.
Some experts believe it may be because fans are getting sick of paying for yet another streaming service.
Laura Sydell, NPR News.
